subject: Re: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
msgSnippet: ... Everything is not XP... every project doesn t come with unit tests... you don t work only on new projects... ... a matter of taste.  It s an old discussion
messageBody:
> I meant to say that it seems not to be a good XP way.

Everything is not XP... every project doesn't come with unit tests... you don't work only on new projects...

> The method name should tell you what this method is. So IMHO,
> testNeedImplement() seems to fit better.

a matter of taste. It's an old discussion (see archive)

> Second, a REAL post-it or a note at the back of your task card seem to work a
> lot more effectively.

not if you work in a team sharing the same code, the same test code... The other members of the team must know what is to be done (in general)

> Actually, I applaud for the other post about the Calendar assertion.
> That seems to be something novel. :)

I agree. But if you write code (1) to remind you to write code (2), what happens if you make a mistake writing the code (1) (error in the date...).

After reflection, I prefer a simple "vbo_todo:" (vbo is my standard visa) and parse the project to be sure that I haven't forgotten any todo.

Some folks will introduce a new javadoc tag and so on, but it's another topic :-)

-Vladimir
